content.title: Tibial and Pedal Bypass (Distal Bypass)
content.definition: Surgical bypass to the tibial arteries (anterior tibial, posterior tibial, peroneal) or pedal arteries (dorsalis pedis, plantar) for critical limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI). Requires autogenous vein conduit; the most technically demanding open revascularization.

key_concepts.description: CLTI with tissue loss or rest pain; failed proximal revascularization; isolated tibial/pedal disease; goal is limb salvage and wound healing, not claudication relief
Autogenous vein mandatory for distal bypass; prosthetic unacceptable (primary patency <20%). GSV preferred; alternatives: contralateral GSV, arm veins, spliced veins
Choose target based on: continuous vessel to foot (angiosome concept); best quality vessel on imaging; vessel supplying wound area. All tibials and pedals are acceptable targets
Foot divided into vascular territories (angiosomes); bypass to artery supplying wound angiosome may improve healing; dorsalis pedis → dorsal foot; posterior tibial → heel/plantar
Bypass to dorsal foot artery; originally described by Ascer; excellent option for forefoot wounds; good patency with vein
Peroneal artery is acceptable target even though doesn't directly reach foot; relies on collaterals to plantar arch; often patent when tibials occluded
5-year primary patency 50-70% with vein; limb salvage rates 70-85% at 5 years; graft may fail after wound heals (acceptable if limb saved)
Primary goal is wound healing and limb salvage, not long-term patency; once wound healed, graft failure may not cause tissue loss (collaterals develop)
Meticulous technique essential; use fine suture (6-0 or 7-0); loupe magnification; gentle tissue handling; heparin; saphenous nerve at risk
Tibial angioplasty and BTK (below-the-knee) intervention increasingly used; may have lower morbidity but inferior patency; hybrid approaches combining both

learning_objectives: Understand that vein is mandatory for tibial/pedal bypass
Apply angiosome concept for target vessel selection
Recognize that limb salvage, not patency, is the goal
Know that peroneal artery is an acceptable target despite indirect foot supply
clinical_pearls: Prosthetic is NOT acceptable for tibial bypass (<20% patency)
Any vein better than prosthetic - use arm veins if needed
Angiosome-directed bypass: bypass to artery supplying wound area
Peroneal is acceptable target (collaterals to foot)
Goal = wound healing; graft can fail after wound heals
Limb salvage 70-85% at 5 years with vein bypass
common_mistakes: Attempting distal bypass without adequate vein
Not considering angiosome concept for target selection
Giving up on limb salvage because of extensive disease
Prioritizing patency over wound healing (wrong goal)
